q: What are the symptoms of a broken leg?
a: The symptoms of a broken leg include severe pain, swelling or bruising, inability to walk, odd shape or bone poking out of the skin, and feeling faint, dizzy, or sick.

q: What should I do if I think I or someone else has broken their leg?
a: If you think you or someone else has broken their leg, immediately go to the nearest accident and emergency (A&E) department. Call 999 for an ambulance if the injury seems severe or you're not able to get to A&E quickly.

q: How is a broken leg treated?
a: A broken leg is treated by immobilization, where a healthcare professional will give painkillers and may fix a splint to secure the leg. If the bone is misaligned, reduction may be needed to put it back into place. In severe cases, surgery may be required to realign and fix the broken bones.

q: What happens during the immobilization treatment for a broken leg?
a: During immobilization treatment, painkillers are given to the patient, and a splint or cast is applied to secure the leg in position and prevent further damage. X-rays are done to assess the fracture, and if the bone is still in position, a plaster cast is usually applied.

q: When should I seek follow-up appointments after a broken leg?
a: An appointment should be made to attend a fracture clinic for follow-up after being discharged from the hospital. Severe fractures may require follow-up appointments every few months for a year or more.

q: How long does it take to recover from a broken leg?
a: The recovery time for a broken leg depends on the severity of the fracture. A minor fracture can take around 6 to 8 weeks to heal, while more severe fractures can take between 3 and 6 months or even longer.

q: What are the possible complications of a broken leg?
a: Possible complications of a broken leg include damaged muscle, nerves, or blood vessels, bone infection, compartment syndrome, and the need for further operation if the bone doesn't heal properly.

q: What are the different types of fractures?
a: The different types of fractures include stress fractures, undisplaced or hairline fractures, displaced fractures, comminuted fractures, and open or compound fractures.

q: What is a stress fracture?
a: A stress fracture is a tiny crack in the bone caused by overuse, and it is commonly seen in athletes.

q: What is an open or compound fracture?
a: An open or compound fracture is a complicated break where the bone has broken through the skin, or the initial injury has exposed the broken bone.

While waiting for medical help, keep the injured leg still, cover any open wounds, and keep the person warm and calm if they are in shock.

q: How is a broken leg treated?
a: The treatment for a broken leg depends on the severity of the fracture. It may involve immobilization with a splint or cast, realigning the bones through reduction, or surgery to fix the broken bones with wires, plates, screws, or rods.

q: What happens during the process of reduction for a broken leg?
a: During the reduction process, a doctor or surgeon will realign the misaligned bones of the broken leg. This is usually done under sedation or anesthesia, and once the bones are in the correct position, a plaster cast can be applied.

q: When are surgeries required for a broken leg?
a: Surgeries for a broken leg are usually required for severe fractures. Surgeons may use metal wires, plates, screws, or rods to realign and fix the broken bones. In some cases, an external fixator may be used. After surgery, a plaster cast is applied.

q: What are the follow-up appointments for a broken leg?
a: After the initial treatment, follow-up appointments at a fracture clinic are scheduled. Orthopedic doctors will monitor the healing process. Severe fractures may require regular follow-up appointments for a year or more, including X-rays to check the progress.
